children.name: fashionable
children.definition: clothes, styles, places or activities that are fashionable are popular at the present time, but will probably only be popular for a short time:
examples: ▪ The store sells fashionable clothes at prices you can afford.

children.name: ▪ a style of painting that was fashionable in the 1930s
examples: ▪ Kate spent her summers in Cape Cod working in a fashionable resort.
▪ They recently opened a cafe on Manhattan’s fashionable East Side.

children.name: cool
children.definition: said to show approval of something that is fashionable, interesting, or attractive -- used especially byyoungpeople:
examples: ▪ He was wearing these really cool sunglasses.
▪ Many young people start smoking because they think it looks cool.

children.name: hot
children.definition: very fashionable now:

children.name: ▪ one of the hot young writers of the decade
examples: ▪ They’re supposed to be the hottest thing since the Beatles.

children.name: trendy
children.definition: very fashionable, often for a short time -- used especiallyhumorouslyor to showdisapproval:
examples: theo xu hướng
▪ a trendy street market in the centre of Paris
▪ Delgado predicts that blonde hair will become trendy this summer.
▪ Trendy bars and restaurants are opening and inexpensive apartments in the area are getting hard to find.

children.name: stylish
children.definition: welldesigned, andattractivein a fashionable way:

children.name: kiểu cách
examples: ▪ She was wearing a stylish black woollen dress.

children.name: chic
children.definition: very fashionable in anexpensiveway, and showing a lot of good judgement about good style:

children.name: thanh lịch
examples: ▪ They live in a chic apartment overlooking the Seine.

children.name: ▪ a chic restaurant in Boston
examples: ▪ The east side of the city has become very chic in the past few years.

children.name: cult
children.definition: fashionable and only known about by a small group of people - use this especially about things orpeoplethat later become veryfamous:
examples: ▪ Alex Garland’s cult novel ‘The Beach’ was later made into a film starring Leonardo di Caprio.

children.name: ▪ 60s cult band The Velvet Underground
examples: ▪ Frankie Knuckles is a cult figure in dance music.

children.name: in
children.definition: fashionable at the present time:

children.name: mốt
examples: ▪ Purple seems to be in this year.

children.name: be the in place
examples: ▪ Gstaad is the in place to go skiing in winter.

children.name: the in thing to do
examples: ▪ Cycling to work has become the in thing to do.

children.name: hip
children.definition: doing things or done according to the latest fashion:

children.name: hợp thời, tân thời
examples: ▪ The South Side is becoming a really hip place to live.
▪ I hate old people who dress like teenagers and think they’re hip.

children.name: happening
children.definition: fashionable and exciting:
examples: ▪ In four to five years, this will be a happening film festival.
▪ The town’s OK, but not what you’d call a happening place.

children.name: style
children.definition: the quality of being fashionable:
examples: young women interested in style rather than comfort
in/out of style
Long skirts are back in style.
The classic black dress is alwaysinstyle.

children.name: be in fashion
children.definition: if clothes, music, places, or activities are in fashion, they are fashionable and popular with many people at the present time:

children.name: hợp thời trang
examples: ▪ Latin music is very much in fashion.
▪ Surprisingly, flared trousers are in fashion again.
▪ Country cottage furniture has been in fashion for a long time now.

children.name: be the fashion
children.definition: to be fashionable:

children.name: là mốt
examples: ▪ I thought it looked ugly, but Iris said white suits were the fashion so I tried it on.

children.name: be the fashion among somebody
examples: ▪ Wearing coats hanging off one shoulder is the fashion among schoolchildren at the moment.

children.name: be the latest thing
children.definition: /be the in thing informalto be the most recent and most popular fashion now:
examples: ▪ When I was growing up, the video game ‘Pong’ was the latest thing.
▪ I know cigars are the in thing, but you’ll never see me smoke one.

children.name: be the latest thing in something
examples: ▪ Herbert’s house looks like a factory , but it’s the latest thing in modern architecture.

children.name: be the in thing to do
examples: ▪ Having a holiday in Ibiza seems to be the in thing to do at the moment.

children.name: be in
children.definition: to be fashionable at the present time: đang thịnh
examples: ▪ Long skirts are in at the moment.

children.name: be all the rage
children.definition: if something, especially an activity, is all the rage, it is very fashionable, and popular with a lot of people, especially for a short time:

children.name: đang thịnh
examples: ▪ Before the war, ragtime was all the rage in the dancehalls.
▪ Buying a cabin in the mountains may be all the rage at the moment, but is it really a sound investment?

children.name: be in vogue
children.definition: if something, especially a style of music, decoration, art etc, is in vogue, it is fashionable at that time with aparticulargroupof people:

children.name: là mốt
examples: ▪ Do you remember when New Wave music was in vogue?
▪ His photographs, stark and sometimes shocking, are very much in vogue with young intellectuals.

children.name: be the height of fashion
children.definition: (= be very fashionable)With her short dress and high boots she was the height of fashion.

children.name: thành mốt, trở nên thịnh
examples: ▪ When did baseball caps come into fashion?
▪ When mini-skirts first came into fashion, women said they’d never wear them.

children.name: come back into fashion
examples: ▪ Short haircuts for men went out for a time, and then they came back into fashion.

children.name: come in
children.definition: to become fashionable, especially for ashortperiod of time:

children.name: thành mốt, trở nên thịnh
examples: ▪ Skateboarding first came in during the early 1980s.
▪ New fashions seem to come in and go out again much more quickly these days.

children.name: make a comeback
children.definition: to become fashionable and popular again,afterhaving been unfashionable for a long period of time:

children.name: thịnh trở lại
examples: ▪ Who’d have thought platform soles would ever make a comeback?
▪ Games like ‘Ludo’ and ‘Snakes and Ladders’ are really making a comeback.

children.name: set the trend
children.definition: to make something that is new fashionable, by doing, using, or wearing it, so that a lot of people copy you:

children.name: tạo nên xu hướng
examples: ▪ Young backpackers set the trend, and now people of all ages are looking for cheap ways to travel around Southeast Asia.

children.name: set the trend of
examples: ▪ To save the planet we must set the trend of caring for the environment.

children.name: fashionable
children.definition: someone who is fashionable wears fashionable clothes, owns fashionable things, and goes to fashionable places:

children.name: hợp thời trang , sành điệu
examples: ▪ This is the latest style of hat worn by fashionable women in Milan.
▪ I’ve never been very fashionable. I’d rather wear what feels comfortable.

children.name: trendy
children.definition: fashionable -- use this especially about someone who you thinktriestoohardto be fashionable:
examples: chạy theo mốt
▪ stylish South Beach cafés filled with trendy young couples
▪ She only talks like that because she wants to sound trendy.

children.name: sophisticated
children.definition: someone who is sophisticated knows a lot about fashionable things and feels confident about being with fashionable people:
examples: sành điệu
▪ a sophisticated woman whose friends included many rich and famous people
▪ a play that will appeal to a sophisticated audience

children.name: fashion victim
children.definition: someone who wears clothes that are fashionable, but that make them looksilly:
examples: ▪ a new designer who will appeal to fashion victims everywhere

children.name: fashion
children.definition: a style of clothes, hair, behaviour etc that is fashionable:
examples: mốt , thời trang
latest fashionthe newest styles of clothes
▪ I always find it hard to keep up with the latest fashions.
fashion in clothes/music etc
▪ changing fashions in popular musicfashion for doing something
▪ Who started this fashion for wearing old army clothes?

children.name: trend
children.definition: /trend/  a way of doing something or a way of thinking that is becoming fashionable:
examples: xu hướng
▪ A lot of the students here don’t think for themselves, they just follow the latest trends.
trend in
▪ Today we’ll be examining the latest trends in kitchen design

children.name: craze/fad
children.definition: a fashion, activity, type of music etc thatsuddenlybecomes very popular, but only remains popular for ashorttime:

children.name: mốt nhất thời
examples: ▪ A new fitness craze from Australia is rapidly catching on.
▪ To no one’s surprise, the macarena proved to be a short-lived fad.

children.name: the latest thing
children.definition: the most fashionable and newest thing to do, wear, or have:

children.name: kiểu mới nhất
examples: ▪ The latest thing is to wear only white clothes.
▪ No matter how expensive, he always has to do the latest thing.

children.name: the latest thing in
examples: ▪ I can remember when eight-track tapes were the latest thing in music.

children.name: vogue
children.definition: a style of music, clothes, art etc that is fashionable with a particulargroupofpeople:
examples: ▪ People’s fondness for wearing black and other dark colours was a vogue I never really liked.

children.name: ▪ a vogue for the paintings of Claude Lorraine
style
children.definition: a particular design or fashion for something such as clothes, hair, furniture etc: thời trang, mốt
examples: Car styles have changed radically in the past 20 years.

children.name: a style consultant
examples: I read the fashion pages in the newspapers to keep up with the latest styles.

children.name: traditional/modern style
examples: The rooms are furnished in a modern style.

children.name: out of fashion
children.definition: no longer fashionable - use this especially aboutclothesandmusic:

children.name: lỗi mốt, lỗi thời
examples: ▪ It seems like all the clothes I buy are out of fashion by the time I wear them.

children.name: go/fall out of fashion
examples: ▪ Rock'n'Roll began in the fifties and has never really gone out of fashion.

children.name: go out
children.definition: especially British to stop being fashionable:

children.name: hết thời , lỗi thời
examples: ▪ Jogging went out when it was found to be harmful for the joints.
▪ I can’t believe you’re wearing those shoes -- they went out years ago!

children.name: unfashionable
children.definition: not fashionable - use this especially about people’s ideas, beliefs, and way of life:

children.name: lỗi thời, lỗi mốt
examples: ▪ She lives in an unfashionable part of West London.
▪ Socialism became unfashionable after the collapse of the Berlin Wall.

children.name: uncool
children.definition: not fashionable, interesting, or attractive - used especially byyoungpeople:

children.name: ▪ a really uncool place for a holidayit’s uncool to do something
examples: ▪ Nowadays it’s considered very uncool to wear fur.

children.name: date
children.definition: tograduallybecome unfashionable, and be replaced with more modern styles, methods, ideas etc:
examples: dated[adjective] fashionable in the past but looking or seeming old-fashioned now::
▪ I loved that album when I bought it a few years ago but it sounds really dated today.
▪ The production was excellent but the costumes looked dated.

children.name: trở nên lỗi thời, lỗi mốt
examples: ▪ The trouble with high fashion clothes is that they date very quickly.
▪ Certain styles of music will never date, and will always be popular.
